canonical_explanation.text:
Anatomy deals with the internal structure of plants. Plant tissues are broadly classified into meristematic tissues (actively dividing) and permanent tissues (differentiated). Meristematic tissues are apical (root and shoot tips), lateral (cambium), and intercalary (at internodes). Permanent tissues include simple tissues — parenchyma (thin-walled, living, with intercellular spaces), collenchyma (thickened at corners, living), and sclerenchyma (thick-walled, dead, lignified) — and complex tissues — xylem (tracheids, vessels, xylem fibres, xylem parenchyma) and phloem (sieve tubes, companion cells, phloem fibres, phloem parenchyma).

The tissue system includes the epidermal tissue system (epidermis, stomata, trichomes), ground tissue system (cortex, pith, medullary rays), and vascular tissue system (xylem and phloem arranged in vascular bundles). Dicot and monocot roots, stems, and leaves differ in their internal anatomy. Dicot stems have open vascular bundles (with cambium) arranged in a ring, while monocot stems have closed bundles (without cambium) scattered throughout. Secondary growth occurs in dicots due to the activity of vascular cambium and cork cambium, producing secondary xylem (wood) and secondary phloem, as well as periderm. Heartwood and sapwood differ in function; annual rings reflect seasonal growth.
rules: Meristematic tissues: apical (primary growth), lateral/intercalary; cells are thin-walled, dense cytoplasm, no vacuoles.
Parenchyma — thin-walled, living, intercellular spaces; collenchyma — corner thickening, living; sclerenchyma — uniformly thick, dead, lignified.
Xylem conducts water and minerals; tracheids and vessels are conducting elements; vessels are present only in angiosperms.
Phloem transports food; sieve tubes and companion cells are the main elements; companion cells are absent in gymnosperms.
Casparian strip in the endodermis of roots controls water and mineral passage into the vascular cylinder.
Open vascular bundles (with cambium) in dicot stems allow secondary growth; closed bundles (without cambium) in monocot stems do not.
Dicot root has limited secondary growth; pith is small or absent; xylem is 2-6 arched.
Monocot root has polyarch xylem, large pith, and no secondary growth.
Secondary growth: vascular cambium produces secondary xylem (inward) and secondary phloem (outward).
Cork cambium (phellogen) produces cork (phellem) outward and secondary cortex (phelloderm) inward — together called periderm.
Heartwood is dark, non-functional, and filled with tannins/resins; sapwood is light and conducts water.
Annual rings are formed due to differential activity of cambium in spring (spring wood) and autumn (autumn wood).

questions.question_text: Which meristematic tissue is responsible for increase in length of the plant?
questions.explanation_correct: Apical meristems are present at the tips of roots and shoots. They are responsible for primary growth, which increases the length of the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lateral meristems (vascular cambium, cork cambium) increase girth. Intercalary meristems help in elongation of internodes but are not the primary tissue for length increase. Apical meristems drive longitudinal growth.

questions.question_text: Sclerenchyma cells are characterised by:

options.text: Thin primary walls and large vacuoles
Uniformly thick, lignified walls and absence of protoplasm at maturity

questions.explanation_correct: Sclerenchyma cells have uniformly thick, lignified secondary walls and are dead at maturity (no protoplasm). They provide mechanical support.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thin walls and vacuoles describe parenchyma. Corner thickening describes collenchyma. Sclerenchyma cells are dead, thick-walled, and lignified.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a complex tissue?
questions.explanation_correct: Xylem is a complex tissue made up of more than one type of cell (tracheids, vessels, xylem fibres, xylem parenchyma) that work together for water conduction and support.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parenchyma, collenchyma, and sclerenchyma are simple tissues composed of only one type of cell. Xylem and phloem are complex tissues with multiple cell types.

questions.question_text: Collenchyma provides mechanical support to growing plant organs because it:

options.text: Has pectin-rich thickening at the corners and is living
Has thin walls and stores food

questions.explanation_correct: Collenchyma cells are living with localized pectin and cellulose thickening at the corners (angular collenchyma). Being living allows them to stretch and provide flexible support to growing organs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dead and lignified cells describe sclerenchyma. Thin-walled food storage describes parenchyma. Collenchyma is living with corner thickening — this provides flexible mechanical support.

questions.question_text: A student examines a plant tissue under the microscope and observes elongated cells with thick, lignified walls and no living contents. The tissue is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: Elongated cells with thick lignified walls and no living contents are characteristic of sclerenchyma fibres. These dead cells provide mechanical strength.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parenchyma cells are thin-walled and living. Collenchyma cells are living with corner thickening. Meristematic cells are small and thin-walled. The described features indicate sclerenchyma.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements of xylem is living?
questions.explanation_correct: Xylem parenchyma is the only living component of xylem. It stores food and helps in lateral conduction of water. Tracheids, vessels, and xylem fibres are all dead at maturity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tracheids, vessels, and xylem fibres are dead at maturity. Only xylem parenchyma retains living protoplasm and functions in food storage and radial water transport.

questions.question_text: Companion cells are associated with which element of phloem?
questions.explanation_correct: Companion cells are closely associated with sieve tube elements in angiosperms. They are connected by plasmodesmata and assist sieve tube elements in transport of food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Companion cells are specifically connected to sieve tubes. Tracheids are xylem elements. Phloem fibres and parenchyma do not have this special association with companion cells.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about vessels is correct?

options.text: They are present in all vascular plants
They are found only in angiosperms (with few exceptions)
They are living cells at maturity
They are the main conducting elements of phloem

questions.explanation_correct: Vessels (trachea) are found predominantly in angiosperms, with a few exceptions in some gymnosperms (e.g., Gnetum). Gymnosperms generally rely on tracheids for water conduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vessels are not present in all vascular plants — most gymnosperms and pteridophytes lack them. They are dead at maturity and are xylem conducting elements, not phloem.

questions.question_text: Sieve tubes lack a nucleus at maturity but remain functional because they are assisted by:
questions.explanation_correct: Sieve tube elements lose their nucleus at maturity. Companion cells, which retain their nucleus, maintain the metabolic activities of sieve tubes through cytoplasmic connections (plasmodesmata).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Xylem parenchyma and tracheids are xylem elements. Phloem fibres provide mechanical support. Companion cells specifically assist enucleate sieve tubes.

questions.question_text: Assertion (A): Intercalary meristems are present in grasses. Reason (R): They help in the regeneration of grass after grazing.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Intercalary meristems are located at the base of internodes in grasses. After grazing, these meristems facilitate rapid regrowth of the cut portions, which is why grasses recover quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are true and the reason explains the assertion. Intercalary meristems allow grasses to regrow from the base after being cut or grazed.

questions.question_text: Aerenchyma is a type of parenchyma found in:
questions.explanation_correct: Aerenchyma is a type of parenchyma with large air spaces that provide buoyancy and facilitate gaseous exchange in aquatic plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Desert plants have thick cuticle and sunken stomata. Aerenchyma is specifically an adaptation of aquatic plants for buoyancy and aeration.

questions.question_text: The two types of sclerenchyma cells are:
questions.explanation_correct: Sclerenchyma consists of two types: fibres (elongated cells with tapering ends) and sclereids (stone cells, which are short and isodiametric). Both are dead and lignified.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tracheids and vessels are xylem elements. Sieve tubes and companion cells are phloem elements. Fibres and sclereids are the two types of sclerenchyma.

questions.question_text: The outermost protective layer of a plant body is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The epidermis is the outermost single-layered protective covering of the plant body. It is usually covered by a waxy cuticle that prevents water loss.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cortex lies between epidermis and vascular tissue. Pith is the central region. Endodermis is the innermost layer of the cortex. The epidermis is the outermost protective layer.

questions.question_text: Stomata are present in the epidermis primarily for:
questions.explanation_correct: Stomata are minute pores in the epidermis of leaves (and sometimes stems) that allow gaseous exchange (CO2 and O2) and regulate transpiration (water vapour loss).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water absorption is done by roots. Mechanical support is by sclerenchyma. Food storage by parenchyma. Stomata facilitate gaseous exchange and transpiration.

questions.question_text: The Casparian strip is found in:
questions.explanation_correct: The Casparian strip is a band of suberin deposited on the radial and tangential walls of endodermal cells in roots. It acts as a barrier to regulate the passage of water and dissolved minerals into the vascular cylinder.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Casparian strips are specific to the endodermis of roots. They are not found in leaf epidermis, pith, or stem cortex. They ensure that water enters the stele through selective pathways.

questions.question_text: Which tissue system comprises xylem and phloem arranged together in vascular bundles?
questions.explanation_correct: The vascular tissue system comprises xylem and phloem arranged in vascular bundles. It is responsible for the transport of water, minerals, and food throughout the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The epidermal tissue system forms the outer covering. The ground tissue system includes cortex and pith. The vascular tissue system consists of xylem and phloem bundles.

questions.question_text: Open vascular bundles are those that:

options.text: Have cambium between xylem and phloem
Lack cambium between xylem and phloem

questions.explanation_correct: Open vascular bundles have a strip of cambium (fascicular cambium) between xylem and phloem, which allows secondary growth. They are found in dicot stems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Closed vascular bundles lack cambium (found in monocots). Open bundles have cambium between xylem and phloem. Both types contain xylem and phloem.

questions.question_text: The ground tissue system includes all tissues except:
questions.explanation_correct: The ground tissue system includes cortex, pith, medullary rays, and pericycle — all tissues except the epidermis and vascular tissues. Epidermis belongs to the epidermal tissue system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cortex, pith, and medullary rays are all part of the ground tissue system. The epidermis is part of the epidermal tissue system, not the ground tissue system.

questions.question_text: Trichomes on the epidermis may function in:

options.text: Preventing water loss and providing protection

questions.explanation_correct: Trichomes (hair-like outgrowths from the epidermis) help in preventing water loss by reducing air flow over the leaf surface and may also provide protection against herbivores and excessive sunlight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water conduction is by xylem. Food storage by parenchyma. Photosynthesis by mesophyll. Trichomes prevent water loss and provide protection.

questions.question_text: In a vascular bundle, if xylem and phloem are arranged on the same radius with phloem towards the outside and xylem towards the inside, it is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In a conjoint collateral vascular bundle, xylem and phloem are on the same radius, with phloem on the outer side and xylem on the inner side. This is the most common type in dicot and monocot stems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Radial bundles have xylem and phloem on alternating radii (found in roots). Bicollateral has phloem on both sides of xylem. Concentric has one tissue surrounding the other.

questions.question_text: Passage cells in the endodermis are found opposite to:
questions.explanation_correct: Passage cells are thin-walled endodermal cells (without suberin deposition) located opposite the protoxylem poles. They allow the passage of water from the cortex into the xylem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Passage cells specifically face the protoxylem, not the phloem or metaxylem. They facilitate water entry into the stele at the protoxylem points.

questions.question_text: Root hairs are extensions of which tissue?
questions.explanation_correct: Root hairs are unicellular tubular extensions of the epiblema (root epidermis). They increase the surface area for absorption of water and minerals from the soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Root hairs arise from the outermost layer of the root, which is the epiblema (also called rhizodermis or piliferous layer). They do not arise from cortex, endodermis, or pericycle.

questions.question_text: In a dicot root, the vascular bundles are arranged in which pattern?

options.text: Radial (xylem and phloem on alternate radii)

questions.explanation_correct: In dicot roots, the vascular arrangement is radial — xylem and phloem are arranged on alternating radii. Dicot roots typically have 2-6 xylem and phloem patches.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conjoint collateral bundles are found in stems. Scattered bundles are in monocot stems. Ring arrangement is in dicot stems. Roots have radial arrangement of xylem and phloem.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of monocot stems?

options.text: Vascular bundles arranged in a ring
Vascular bundles scattered throughout the ground tissue

questions.explanation_correct: In monocot stems, numerous vascular bundles are scattered throughout the ground tissue. They are closed (lack cambium) and are surrounded by a sclerenchymatous bundle sheath.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ring arrangement and vascular cambium are features of dicot stems. Monocot stems have scattered vascular bundles and lack a distinct cortex-pith differentiation.

questions.question_text: The number of xylem arches in a dicot root is typically:
questions.explanation_correct: Dicot roots have 2 to 6 (diarch to hexarch) xylem patches alternating with the same number of phloem patches. Monocot roots are polyarch (more than 6).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polyarch condition (more than 6 xylem arches) is typical of monocot roots. Dicot roots have fewer xylem arches — usually 2 to 6.

questions.question_text: A cross-section of a stem shows vascular bundles arranged in a ring with a distinct cortex and pith. The vascular bundles have cambium between xylem and phloem. This stem belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Vascular bundles in a ring, distinct cortex and pith, and the presence of cambium (open bundles) are all features of a dicot stem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monocot stems have scattered bundles without cambium. The ring arrangement with open vascular bundles and distinct cortex/pith is characteristic of dicot stems.

questions.question_text: In monocot leaves, the mesophyll is:

options.text: Differentiated into palisade and spongy parenchyma

questions.explanation_correct: In monocot leaves (isobilateral leaves), the mesophyll is NOT differentiated into palisade and spongy layers. It consists of undifferentiated, loosely arranged cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dicot leaves (dorsiventral) have differentiated palisade and spongy mesophyll. Monocot leaves have undifferentiated mesophyll — cells are isodiametric throughout.

questions.question_text: In the anatomy of a dicot leaf, palisade parenchyma is located:
questions.explanation_correct: In a dicot leaf (dorsiventral leaf), palisade parenchyma is located on the adaxial (upper) side. It consists of elongated, closely packed cells rich in chloroplasts for photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spongy parenchyma is on the abaxial (lower) side. Palisade tissue is on the adaxial (upper) side of dicot leaves, giving them a darker upper surface.

questions.question_text: In a monocot root, the pith is:
questions.explanation_correct: Monocot roots have a large, well-developed pith composed of parenchymatous cells. In dicot roots, the pith is small or inconspicuous.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dicot roots have small or absent pith. Monocot roots have a large pith. The pith is made of parenchyma, not sclerenchyma.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is NOT found in a monocot stem?
questions.explanation_correct: Monocot stems do not have a distinct cortex and pith. The ground tissue is homogeneous, with vascular bundles scattered throughout. Distinct cortex and pith differentiation is a dicot stem feature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scattered bundles, closed bundles, and sclerenchymatous hypodermis are all monocot stem features. The absence of distinct cortex-pith differentiation is what distinguishes monocot from dicot stems.

questions.question_text: The bundle sheath in monocot leaves is composed of:
questions.explanation_correct: In monocot leaves, each vascular bundle is surrounded by a bundle sheath of large-sized parenchymatous cells. In C4 plants (many monocots), these cells contain chloroplasts (Kranz anatomy).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The bundle sheath consists of large parenchyma cells, not collenchyma, sclerenchyma, or sieve tubes. This is important in C4 photosynthesis found in many monocot grasses.

questions.question_text: In a dicot stem, the vascular bundles are:
questions.explanation_correct: In a dicot stem, vascular bundles are open (have cambium) and arranged in a ring. This allows secondary growth by cambial activity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Closed, scattered bundles are in monocot stems. Radial alternating arrangement is in roots. Dicot stems have open, ring-arranged bundles.

questions.question_text: Endarch xylem (protoxylem towards the centre, metaxylem towards the periphery) is characteristic of:
questions.explanation_correct: In stems, the xylem is endarch — protoxylem (first-formed xylem) is towards the centre (pith) and metaxylem (later-formed) is towards the periphery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots show exarch xylem (protoxylem towards the periphery). Stems show endarch xylem (protoxylem towards the centre). This is an important anatomical distinction.

questions.question_text: Exarch xylem (protoxylem towards the periphery) is found in:

options.text: Roots of both dicots and monocots

questions.explanation_correct: Exarch xylem — with protoxylem towards the periphery and metaxylem towards the centre — is found in roots of both dicots and monocots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both dicot and monocot stems have endarch xylem. Exarch xylem is a characteristic feature of roots, regardless of whether they are dicot or monocot.

questions.question_text: Secondary growth in dicot stems is primarily due to the activity of:
questions.explanation_correct: Secondary growth (increase in girth) in dicot stems is caused by two lateral meristems: vascular cambium (produces secondary xylem and phloem) and cork cambium/phellogen (produces cork and secondary cortex).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apical meristem causes primary growth (length). Intercalary meristem elongates internodes. Secondary growth requires lateral meristems — vascular cambium and cork cambium.

questions.question_text: The vascular cambium produces secondary xylem on which side?
questions.explanation_correct: The vascular cambium produces secondary xylem (wood) on its inner side (towards the pith) and secondary phloem on its outer side (towards the bark).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Secondary xylem is deposited inward and secondary phloem outward. More secondary xylem is formed than secondary phloem, which is why trees have a large woody core.

questions.question_text: The periderm consists of:
questions.explanation_correct: The periderm is the protective outer covering that replaces the epidermis during secondary growth. It consists of phellem (cork), phellogen (cork cambium), and phelloderm (secondary cortex).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Epidermis, cortex, and endodermis are primary tissues. The periderm is a secondary protective tissue consisting of phellem (cork), phellogen (cork cambium), and phelloderm (secondary cortex).

questions.question_text: Heartwood differs from sapwood in that heartwood:

options.text: Is non-functional in water conduction and filled with tannins, resins, etc.

questions.explanation_correct: Heartwood (duramen) is the inner, older, darker wood that is no longer functional in water conduction. It is filled with tannins, resins, oils, and other organic compounds that make it durable and resistant to decay.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active water conduction and lighter colour are features of sapwood (alburnum). Heartwood is dark, non-functional in conduction, and located in the central region of the stem.

questions.question_text: Annual rings in trees are formed due to:

options.text: Differential activity of cambium in different seasons

questions.explanation_correct: Annual rings are formed due to the differential activity of vascular cambium in spring/summer (wide vessels, spring wood) and autumn/winter (narrow vessels, autumn wood). Each ring represents one year's growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Annual rings are not formed by apical meristems or cork cambium. The alternation of spring wood (wider cells) and autumn wood (narrower cells) by vascular cambium creates the annual rings.

questions.question_text: Cork (phellem) is impervious to water because it is impregnated with:
questions.explanation_correct: Cork cells are impregnated with suberin, a waxy substance that makes the cell walls impervious to water and gases. This is why cork provides excellent insulation and protection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lignin strengthens sclerenchyma. Cutin is found in the cuticle of epidermis. Pectin is in cell walls. Suberin is specifically deposited in cork cells making them waterproof.

questions.question_text: Lenticels are present on the bark of trees to facilitate:
questions.explanation_correct: Lenticels are lens-shaped openings in the bark that permit the exchange of gases between the internal tissues and the atmosphere. They compensate for the loss of stomata after secondary growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cork is impervious to gases, so lenticels serve as pores for gaseous exchange. They do not absorb water, store food, or perform photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Spring wood (early wood) differs from autumn wood (late wood) in having:
questions.explanation_correct: Spring wood (early wood) is formed during the favourable growing season. It has wider vessels with thinner walls, more parenchyma, and is lighter in colour compared to autumn wood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Narrow vessels and darker colour characterise autumn wood (late wood). Spring wood is lighter, with wider vessels for greater water conduction during the active growth period.

questions.question_text: Secondary growth does NOT occur in:
questions.explanation_correct: Monocot stems generally lack secondary growth because their vascular bundles are closed (lack cambium). Dicot stems, dicot roots, and gymnosperm stems undergo secondary growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dicot stems, dicot roots, and gymnosperm stems all undergo secondary growth through cambial activity. Monocot stems generally do not undergo secondary growth.

questions.question_text: The age of a tree can be estimated by counting the:
questions.explanation_correct: The science of counting annual rings to determine the age of a tree is called dendrochronology. Each annual ring represents one year of growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Branches, height, and bark thickness do not directly correlate with age. Annual rings provide the most reliable estimate of a tree's age.

questions.question_text: Assertion (A): Bark includes all tissues exterior to the vascular cambium. Reason (R): Bark is formed as a result of activity of cork cambium only.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is true — bark refers to all tissues outside the vascular cambium (including secondary phloem, cortex, and periderm). However, the reason is false because bark includes secondary phloem produced by vascular cambium, not just periderm from cork cambium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bark includes both periderm (from cork cambium) and secondary phloem (from vascular cambium). So saying bark is formed only by cork cambium activity is incorrect.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of tissues from outside to inside in an old dicot stem?

options.text: Cork → cortex → phloem → cambium → xylem → pith

questions.explanation_correct: In an old dicot stem with secondary growth, the sequence from outside to inside is: cork (periderm) → cortex (remnants) → secondary phloem → vascular cambium → secondary xylem → pith.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In old stems, epidermis is replaced by cork. Phloem is always outside the cambium and xylem inside it. Option A correctly shows the sequence after secondary growth.

questions.question_text: Bulliform cells (motor cells) are found in the upper epidermis of:
questions.explanation_correct: Bulliform cells (motor cells) are large, bubble-shaped epidermal cells found in the upper epidermis of monocot leaves, especially grasses. They help in the rolling and unrolling of leaves to reduce water loss.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bulliform cells are specific to monocot (grass) leaves. They are not found in dicot leaves, roots of any type. They are an adaptation to control transpiration.

questions.question_text: The cuticle on the epidermis is made of:
questions.explanation_correct: The cuticle is a waxy layer made of cutin (a fatty substance) deposited on the outer surface of the epidermis. It reduces water loss through transpiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Suberin is found in cork cells. Lignin is in sclerenchyma and xylem. Cellulose is the main component of cell walls. The cuticle is specifically made of cutin.

questions.question_text: Chlorenchyma is a type of parenchyma that:
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorenchyma is parenchyma that contains chloroplasts and is specialised for photosynthesis. It is found in the mesophyll of leaves and in green stems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water storage parenchyma is found in succulents. Starch storage parenchyma is found in tubers. Chlorenchyma specifically contains chloroplasts for photosynthesis and is living.

questions.question_text: The interfascicular cambium that forms during secondary growth originates from:

options.text: Medullary ray parenchyma cells between vascular bundles

questions.explanation_correct: Interfascicular cambium arises from the dedifferentiation of medullary ray parenchyma cells located between vascular bundles. It joins with fascicular cambium to form a complete cambial ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pericycle gives rise to lateral roots in roots. Epidermis and pith do not form cambium. The medullary ray parenchyma between bundles redifferentiates to form interfascicular cambium.
